qas.question: What is one piece that makes up an antenna system?
What is created by a portion of a radio waves energy reversing?
A term that refers to the highs and lows of power in electro magnetic waves is?
Impedance matching makes an important difference in what antenna function?

context: As an electro-magnetic wave travels through the different parts of the antenna system (<a0_0>radio<a0_0/>, feed line, antenna, free space) it may encounter differences in impedance (E/H, V/I, etc.). At each interface, depending on the impedance match, some fraction of the wave's energy will reflect back to the source, forming a <a1_0>standing wave<a1_0/> in the feed line. The ratio of maximum power to minimum power in the wave can be measured and is called the <a2_0>standing wave ratio<a2_0/> (SWR). A SWR of 1:1 is ideal. A SWR of 1.5:1 is considered to be marginally acceptable in low power applications where power loss is more critical, although an SWR as high as 6:1 may still be usable with the right equipment. Minimizing impedance differences at each interface (impedance matching) will reduce SWR and maximize <a3_0>power transfer<a3_0/> through each part of the antenna system.
